Message.Title: M. Dell isn’t upping ante
Message.Msg: M. Dell isn’t upping ante NYPost Michael Dell doesn’t appear to be letting a little thing like a competing offer for his ailing PC maker force him to up his offer, sources tell The Post. The executive and Silver Lake, his partner in the $13.65-per-share — or $24.4 billion — bid to take the Round Rock, Texas, PC maker private aren’t expected to budge on the bid, sources said. The two are expected to stand pat despite a rival bid from Carl Icahn and prodding from Dell Inc.’s special committee to raise their offer.

Message.Title: $15 recommended by Yackman Asset Management as minimum bid
Message.Msg: According to a Seeking Alfa article; Silver Lake, Michael Dell's (DELL) partner in his $24.4B bid to take Dell (DELL) private, is reportedly wavering in its commitment amid the firm's deteriorating performance and worsening debt markets. Meanwhile, several of Dell's largest investors have told the board to up the $13.65-a-share offer or risk shareholder rejection, or come up with a Plan B in case the proposal fails. Over $15 a share would probably be enough to win shareholder backing, says Dell investor Yacktman Asset Management. As a personal comment, anything less than $15 per share would be criminal as far as I'm concerned

Topic.Title: $15 recommended by Yackman Asset Management as minimum bid

Message.Msg: i'd rather own the SHARES and be able to participate on the UPSIDE. the stock will come back - i don't want to be forced to sell at the LOW!

Topic.Title: $15 recommended by Yackman Asset Management as minimum bid

Message.Msg: What is interesting to me is if everyone of these big investors thought Dell shares were worth so much more, then how did the price get so depressed? They should have been supporting the stock rather than allowing it to be sold down. If it should have been priced above $15 and so many think so, then they should all be owning over 100 million shares at this ridiculously low price. It was only when Dell decided to actually take it private that people came out of the woodwork against the purchase. Dell has been threatening to go private for years, but no institution has been out there loving the stock so much that they were willing to buy more at the undervalued price. They, in fact, sold it down. Just look at the institutional ownership and see the culprits that undervalued the stock and the volumes of institutions that are short Dell. All of the negative does not line up with the $15 call options for Aug, Sept and Oct though. Of course it could all be cheap hedges both put and call.

Message.Title: Disingenuous Michael Dell
Message.Msg: "Dell's go-private effort shows the disingenuous nature of hoarding cash." "Michael Dell probably didn't mind the stock falling, [and] now he wants to take Dell private and, voila, the balance sheet will be fully utilized to finance his purchase of the company." "In other words management actions show that when it is our money, it needs to be held conservatively and reserved for strategic flexibility, but when it is their money, they don't need so much rainy day cash and they would like to see the balance sheet working harder to generate the maximum return on equity." - David Einhorn

Message.Title: If Carl Icahn wanted DELL
Message.Msg: Carl Icahn could easily do a hostile bid at even $14.65 and buy enough out of the market to own the company. He wouldn't have to do $15, I don't think. For that matter, he may be the one out there buying everything up right now. Someone was supporting the price around 13.28 and now someone is holding the bid up again. Icahn has the means to do what he wants if he wants bad enough. It could become a vindictive move and he could win. There could also be enough bidders out there to buy up the pieces of Dell just to see the extra player go away in an ever shrinking market. Icahn could have already have talked with those that would want some pieces and it would be worth it to them to see Dell go away. I'm surprised that Microsoft hasn't kicked in more than the $2 billion reported to be in play for the buyout since Dell has been such a loyal customer. I'm betting that MSFT hates Icahn and doesn't want him in the neighborhood of Dell.

Topic.Title: Why doesn't Dell just add some debt and issue $15 dividend?

Message.Msg: Any comments on this Icahn supposedly has $5.2 debt already. Thus, Dell should be able to find $5.2 billion in debt at least. Dell earned about $3 billion lat year. Thus Dell could easily use about $1 billion in cash for a rainy day fund. 9419+5200=14619. 14619/1755= $8.33 special dividend. Then based on 3 billion fcf. They could issue about $1.50 annual dividend. So if the stock drops to $5 after the special, the yield will be 20%.

Topic.Title: Who would I contact if I want to offer a proposal to board?

Message.Msg: I think it is pretty obvious Dell, the CEO, the board, and Icahn (not as much) want to rip us off. The company can easily issue some debt and a massive special dividend and a massive regular dividend. The stock can handle a $1.50 regular dividend plus a $9 special dividend.
